results.title: Watch out for my plant
results.brief_description: A young inner-city boy struggles to grow a plant in a tiny patch of dirt. We see his determination, a special relationship with an older man and the flowering and destruction of the plant. Shows that everyone can do something about his environment, given initiative, responsibility and perseverance. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Wastewater to wood
results.creator_credit: Film Victoria, Streets Ahead Productions and Russ Street
results.brief_description: A short documentary that examines the recycling of waste water for use. This project is one that is being undertaken jointly by the Forest Commission Reclaimed Water Committee and local sewerage authorities.

results.title: Wasted resources
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Katherine Smalley
results.brief_description: Programs to find employment for the mentally retarded have been producing some encouraging results in Canada. Once dubious employers who participated are finding themselves with reliable help. The film shows people employed in a variety of different jobs, and social workers describe the programs they have developed.

results.title: Waste not want not
results.creator_credit: WGBH (Boston), Chedd-Angier Productions, Film Australia and Vivian Ducat
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
This program examines tales of garbage barges, toxic dumping, overflowing landfills and sewage polluting coastal waters. But it also tells of some imaginative and economically viable ways of not only disposing of waste materials, but also of making use of them for the benefit of the local communities who produce them. Narrated by Karina Kelly.

results.title: Waste not
results.creator_credit: United Nations Television and Robert Dierbeck
results.brief_description: A survey of the world energy crisis using such examples as the power shortage in the UK in 1973. Workers were put on a three-day week, some pubs and shops reverted to gaslight and a ‘Switch off’ campaign saved 20 percent of power usage. Architects with this in mind start to design energy saving buildings. Wind power and solar panels are discussed and demonstrated. Third world man-power in agriculture is contrasted with the developed world’s high output of farm produce with modern techniques using large energy consuming machines and fertilisers made from petro-chemicals. Narrated by Tom Dunn with camera by Joseph Cabbibo. Also produced by The New York State Education Department and The Ontario Educational Communications Authority.

results.title: Wastage of human resources
results.brief_description: …The high childbirth death-rate, mortality among young children from accidents and environmentally caused diseases, boys and girls put into time-wasting and dead-end jobs for want of better education and vocational guidance, able-bodied men unemployed, and the aged drifting hopelessly to death, are the hard facts in many parts of the world today. Capping all this in the needless wastage of human manpower is the frightful toll of war Quoted from a review published in the ‘Sun News-Pictorial’ Melbourne 14 April 1950.

results.title: Washtenaw playground
results.creator_credit: Ralph Lopatin, Paul Hogan, Mario Fratini and Joan Bressler
results.brief_description: The playground for the Washtenaw Intermediate Unit of Ann Arbor, Michigan is the most recent and most successful playground built with the assistance of the Playground Clearing House. With careful advance planning, the entire playground was built in three days. It involved the use of over a half million dollars worth of construction equipment. Narrated by Sherry Steiner.

results.title: Washington: the first seven years
results.creator_credit: Turners Film Productions and David Cox
results.brief_description: A new town in a coal mining area, Washington in the United Kingdom was the twenty-first new town to be built in post-war Britain. The third to be built in N.E. England. Reflects on the days of the coal mining towns and the low standard of living. Washington represents a new world of living in modern England surrounded by new motorways - industrial areas separated from residential areas - social and industrial development. Washington is made up of several villages with a proposed town centre to unite the villages. Directed and photographed by David Cox.

results.title: Washington square
results.creator_credit: Hollywood Picture, Caravan Pictures, Alchemy Filmworks, Roger Birnbaum, Julie Bergman Sender and Agnieszka Holland
results.brief_description: Jennifer Jason Leigh stars as Catherine Sloper, a ‘plain’ and socially inept young woman with a domineering father who blames his daughter for the death of his wife during childbirth. Incapable of expressing any love or tenderness towards his daughter, Dr. Sloper (Albert Finney) is immediately suspicious of the handsome young suitor who starts pursuing her. Believing that Morris Townsend’s (Ben Chaplin) interest in Catherine is motivated by her wealth, Dr. Sloper does everything in his power to forbid the liaison. Willing to surrender her inheritance in order to marry Morris, Catherine gradually realises that nobody wants her to make this sacrifice. Also stars Maggie Smith and Judith Ivey. Based upon the novel by Henry James which was filmed as ‘The Heiress’ by William Wyler. Screenplay by Carol Doyle. Photographed by Jerzy Zielinski. Edited by David Siegel. Music by Jan P. Kaczmarek.
